name: East African Music
description: Traditions which originate from the eastern subregion of the African continent, encompassing a wide variety of cultures and styles.

children.name: Acholi Music
children.description: Music of the Acholi people, who inhabit a region known as “Acholiland,” spanning parts of northern Uganda and southern South Sudan.

children.name: Baganda Music
children.description: Music of the Baganda people, a Bantu ethnic group indigenous to Uganda.

children.name: Benga
children.description: Kenyan popular music based around the Traditional Folk Music of the Luo people from the area.

children.name: Beni
children.description: Festive Zanzibari Marching Band music that emerged in the late 19th century.

children.name: Bongo Flava
children.description: Tanzanian genre originating in the mid-1990s in the Dar es Salaam area, combining the influence of Rhythm & Blues, Afrobeat, and Dancehall with native Tanzanian styles like Taarab and Muziki wa dansi.

children.name: Comorian Music
children.description: Music of the Comoros Islands and Mayotte off the eastern coast of Africa, combining influences from other East African Music and Malagasy Music.

children.name: Dinka Music
children.description: Music of the Dinka people, the most populous ethnic group of South Sudan.

children.name: Genge
children.description: Combines elements of Dancehall with various traditions of Kenya.

children.name: Gogo Music
children.description: Music of the Gogo People (Wagogo), who inhabit Central Tanzania.

children.name: Inkiranya
children.description: Influential drumming style originating in Burundi carried out by a percussion ensemble.

children.name: Kapuka
children.description: Includes elements from Hip Hop and Reggae, as well as Kenyan traditions.

children.name: Kidandali
children.description: Popular form of Ugandan music, originally derived from Kadongo kamu and Soukous.

children.name: Kidumbak
children.description: Centered on two small kidumbak drums, fiddle, and singer; closely related to Taarab.

children.name: Marrabenta
children.description: Fast, guitar driven, urban dance music from Mozambique that originated in Maputo in the 1950s, taking cues from Mozambican folk and a variety of foreign sounds.

children.name: Mchiriku
children.description: Pairs amplified keyboards with hectic, intricate percussion and vocals drawn from earlier Tanzanian styles.

children.name: Muziki wa dansi
children.description: Popular in Tanzania with strong connections to Soukous and often associated with Jazz, whose name means "dance music" in Swahili.

children.name: Ngoma
children.description: Played in Swahili-speaking African countries; primarily focused on rhythm.

children.name: Omutibo
children.description: Mid-20th century Kenyan popular music which centres around a fingerpicked acoustic guitar.

children.name: Shilluk Music
children.description: All musical forms of the Shilluk people of the Upper Nile region of South Sudan.

children.name: Singeli
children.description: Developed in Tanzania in the mid-2000s; fuses incredibly rapid beats, usually between 180-300BPM, with MCing and musical influences from older Tanzanian genres.

children.name: Soga Music
children.description: Music of the Soga people, a Bantu ethnic group residing in Eastern Uganda.

children.name: Taarab
children.description: Prominent violin, qanun (an Egyptian zither-like instrument), and sung Swahili poetry, often accompanied by African drums and other percussion.

children.name: Timbila
children.description: Tradition of the Chopi people of the Inhambane province of Mozambique, named for the mbila, the wooden xylophone-like instrument on which it is played.

children.name: Twa Music
children.description: Music of the Great Lakes Twa people.
